title: Inside the macabre witchcraft museum displaying 'corpse trousers' made of human skin
text:
Inside the macabre witchcraft museum displaying 'corpse trousers' made of human skin A museum displaying relics of 17th century witchcraft has proved a hit as one of the world's macabre tourist attractions   Share   Comments By Chris Baynes 23:14, 17 FEB 2017 News A witch in the museum's sorcerer's cottage (Photo: IngÃ³lfur JÃºlÃ­usson)   Share   Comments Get daily   Trousers made from skin sliced off the legs of a corpse don't exactly scream 'family day out'.
But an Icelandic museum displaying relics of 17th century sorcery has proved a hit as one of the world's macabre tourist attractions. 
The Museum of Icelandic Sorcery and Witchcraft, in the tiny coastal town Hólmavík, is a window into one of the country's darkest chapters.
At least 17 people were burned alive at the stake between 1654 and 1690 after being accused by witch hunters of practising black magic.
'Necropants' were made of human skin (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) Many of the reported cases of sorcery stemmed from the Westfjords peninsula, where the museum is located, and the area remains steeped in folklore.
About 15,000 visitors a year pass through the museum's doors to cast their eyes over bizarre and gruesome exhibits including ritualistic stones, a milk-sucking demon and a sorcerer's cottage. 
Read More Inside the world's largest penis museum man built because 'somebody had to do it' Witches were feared to raise up skeletons from the ground during the 17th century (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) A parchment display magical symbols (Photo: Museum of Icelandic Sorcery and) But the most eye-opening item on display is a pair of necropants - 'nábrók' in Icelandic - made from the skin of a dead man.
Legend had it the ghastly trousers could give the wearer bottomless wealth.
The sorcerer's cottage (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) Relics of a spell to know who has stolen from you (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) How 17th century Icelanders dealt with ghosts (Photo: IngÃ³lfur JÃºlÃ­usson) They were made by digging up the corpse of a friend - with prior permission - after they died of natural causes.
The dead person's skin would then be flayed from the waist down so their surviving friend could step inside the necropants, which would supposedly then stick to their own skin.
The wearer was the required to complete the ritual by stealing a coin from a poor widow to keep by their scrotum along with a parchment inscribed with a magical sign.
Read More Are these creepiest museum exhibits ever? Macabre display includes DEMONIC NUN and 'monkey chef' holding decapitated cat's head The Sorcerer of Strandir (Photo: ÃgÃºst Atlason) The milk-sucking tilberi (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) The museum's necropants are a disturbingly lifeline replica made using the measurements of a local man.
If that wasn't enough, visitors will also be confronted by skeletons bursting through the floorboards and 'tilberi' - frightening two-headed demons that were supposed to suckle on farmers' cows to steal milk.
The sorcerer's cottage (Photo: SigurÃ°ur Atlason) (Photo: Agust Atlason) Witches were said to make their demons by winding wool around a rib stolen from a corpse in a cemetery.
It is said the creatures would then repay their human creators by brining them endless supplies of milk to make butter.
The museum, curated by Sigurður Atlason, faced opposition from conservatives when it first opened in 2000.
But it has since won over locals and expanded, brining valuable tourism to the area's economy.
